First_Section_Content.value:
<p>During Women’s History Month, it is important to celebrate the social, economic, cultural, and political achievements of women. This month also marks a call to action for accelerating gender parity. Many of the unique challenges women have traditionally faced when seeking to advance to senior levels appear to remain.</p>
<p>In the quest to advance women, MIT Sloan Professor Fiona Murray and Senior Lecturer Elsbeth Johnson, co-faculty of the <a href="https://executive.mit.edu/course/womens-leadership-program/a054v00000rfdVZAAY.html" target="_blank">Women's Leadership Program</a>, advocate for a critical shift towards embracing power. Women often excel in influence and communication, yet may shy away from seeking power directly. This hesitation can hinder progress towards senior executive roles, despite exceptional expertise across fields like science, law, or finance. The challenge is to normalize the pursuit of power among women, encouraging them to step forward and claim their place at the decision-making table. Murray and Johnson offer six approaches to help aspiring women leaders address these challenges and break through the glass ceiling—once and for all.</p>

Article_Title.value: It may be time to change your relationship to power

Summary.value: <p>Despite the many advances women have made in the workforce over these past decades, many of the unique challenges women have traditionally faced when seeking to advance to senior levels appear to remain. Here are six tips from MIT's Fiona Murray and Elsbeth Johnson for claiming power and breaking through the glass ceiling once and for all.</p>

Featured_Quote.value: It’s OK for us to say we want to get our hands on power, because we know we can make a difference once we’ve got it.

content.title: It may be time to change your relationship to power

First_Section_Content.value: <p>As the technological revolution reshapes the global financial landscape, the traditional banking sector in Mexico is being challenged by breakthrough technologies such as blockchain, fintech, and insurtech. Standing on the frontline of this transition, José (Alex) Espinosa, the driving force behind the technological transformation of Walmart Mexico, decided it was time to take the next step. Armed with a desire to stay ahead of the curve, he embarked on a journey to equip himself with the latest tools and trends through <a href="https://executive.mit.edu/earn-a-certificate/advanced-certificate-for-executives/a0F6g000005RcblEAC.html" target="_blank">MIT Sloan's Advanced Certificate for Executives (ACE) program</a>. "MIT's ACE program provided the perfect platform to gain these insights, helping me to spearhead innovation in our retail financial solutions ecosystem." Espinosa's ACE journey was marked by a rigorous curriculum, world-class faculty, and enlightening interactions with a diverse cohort. Leveraging his strong technical background, he focused on understanding emerging trends in global markets, data monetization strategies, and principles of sustainable platform management. The courses provided him with a comprehensive understanding of how technology, operations, strategy, innovation, and management are intricately linked, shaping his approach to driving technological transformation in the financial sector. "The ACE program not only equipped me with the knowledge to understand the emerging trends in my market and provided me with a fresh perspective on managing innovation in the financial sector but also honed my leadership and communication skills, enabling me to build a high-performing and motivated team."</p>
